Methodology.models_description: In the realm of environmental research and fire management, theutilization of advanced modeling tools is indispensable, and one suchpowerful framework is the WRF-CHIMERE chemical transport model. Thisintegrated system combines the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF)model with the CHIMERE chemistry-transport model, enabling acomprehensive understanding of the atmospheric dynamics and chemicalprocesses associated with forest fires. WRF-CHIMERE excels in simulatingthe intricate interplay between meteorological conditions and thedispersion of pollutants emitted during wildfires. The modelincorporates complex terrain features and provides a robust platform forassessing the spatial and temporal distribution of pollutants arisingfrom forest fires. Researchers leverage WRF-CHIMERE to gain insightsinto the impact of wildfires on air quality, helping to formulateinformed strategies for mitigation and resource allocation. Through itssophisticated algorithms and dynamic representation of atmosphericinteractions, WRF-CHIMERE stands as a cornerstone in advancing ourcomprehension of the complex dynamics involved in forest fire modeling.
Methodology.air_quality_description: The Air Quality Index (AQI) is a numerical scale used to communicate how polluted the air currently is or how polluted it is forecast to become. It provides a way to quantify and communicate the impact of air pollutants on public health. The AQI presented in this website is calculated based on the hourly concentrations of several major air pollutants, including particulate matter (PM10 and PM2.5), ground-level ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) and nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>).
Methodology.index_sub: (based on hourly pollutant concentrations in µg/m3)
